unnormalised: The year was 2018. I remember Adv. Mehra, a seasoned lawyer with over 20 yrs of experience, pacing nervously. Our firm, "Desai & Associates," was handling the merger of "Sharma Industries" and "Verma Corp," a deal valued at ₹500 crores. The devil, as always, was in the details, specifically, Clause 17B of the agreement which dealt with intellectual property rights. He kept muttering about the Companies Act, Section 230, sub-section 5, needing to be meticulously followed.
normalised: The year was two thousand and eighteen. I remember Advocate Mehra, a seasoned lawyer with over twenty years of experience, pacing nervously. Our firm, "Desai and Associates," was handling the merger of "Sharma Industries" and "Verma Corporation," a deal valued at rupee five hundred crore. The devil, as always, was in the details, specifically, Clause seventeen B of the agreement which dealt with intellectual property rights. He kept muttering about the Companies Act, Section two hundred and thirty, sub-section five, needing to be meticulously followed.

unnormalised: The main hurdle was the due diligence. Verma Corp had a subsidiary, “Verma Innovations Pvt. Ltd.” Their patent filings were, let’s just say, creative. Mr. Verma, the owner, wasn't keen on disclosing everything. "It's just a formality, Mehra ji," he’d say, sipping his chai. But Adv. Mehra wouldn't budge. "According to the Competition Act, 2002, full disclosure is mandatory," he'd insist, his voice firm. We had to verify everything, from their GST registration to their Memorandum of Association.
normalised: The main hurdle was the due diligence. Verma Corporation had a subsidiary, “Verma Innovations Private Limited.” Their patent filings were, let’s just say, creative. Mister Verma, the owner, wasn't keen on disclosing everything. "It's just a formality, Mehra ji," he’d say, sipping his chai. But Advocate Mehra wouldn't budge. "According to the Competition Act, two thousand and two, full disclosure is mandatory," he'd insist, his voice firm. We had to verify everything, from their G-S-T registration to their Memorandum of Association.

unnormalised: Then came the shareholder approvals. Sharma Industries needed a 75% majority vote, as per SEBI guidelines. A last-minute objection from a minority shareholder, Mr. R. Kumar, threatened to derail the whole deal. He claimed insider trading, referencing a news article from 03/04/2018. It took us 2 weeks and countless meetings to convince him that everything was above board and that compliance with the laws of the land was paramount.
normalised: Then came the shareholder approvals. Sharma Industries needed a seventy five percent majority vote, as per S-E-B-I guidelines. A last-minute objection from a minority shareholder, Mister R. Kumar, threatened to derail the whole deal. He claimed insider trading, referencing a news article from third April two thousand and eighteen. It took us two weeks and countless meetings to convince him that everything was above board and that compliance with the laws of the land was paramount.

unnormalised: The final hurdle was the regulatory approval from the Ministry of Corporate Affairs. Filing Form MGT-14 was just the beginning. We needed clearance from the CCI (Competition Commission of India) too. The process involved submitting tons of documents and attending countless hearings. The whole process felt like it would never end.

unnormalised: Finally, on 15/11/2018, we received the official notification. The merger was approved. Adv. Mehra, usually so composed, let out a whoop of joy. It was a triumph, a testament to his meticulousness, his unwavering adherence to the letter of the law, and of course, his encyclopedic knowledge of corporate law! It was a reminder that even in the cutthroat world of mergers and acquisitions, integrity and compliance are non-negotiable, especially when crores of rupees are involved.
